stories.story: I’ll never forget the night I cooked my mother’s arroz con pollo for a full house at the bistro. The kitchen was alive with music and laughter, and as the aroma filled the air, I felt my mother’s presence beside me. After service, a guest told me the dish tasted like home. That’s why I cook—to bring people together, to keep memories alive in every bite.

There was a night, years ago, when I made arroz con pollo for a packed house. The kitchen was busy, and I felt my mother with me. Someone said it tasted like home. That’s what I love about cooking—sharing memories.
I remember making a special dish—arroz con pollo, I think—for a lot of people. The kitchen was loud, full of life. Someone said it reminded them of home. That meant a lot to me.
There was a night, a dish, a busy kitchen. I cooked. Someone said it tasted like home. I remember feeling happy.
A dish. Kitchen. People. Someone said home.
